update.description:
This pull request introduces the BuoyancyPlugin, which simulates the force opposing gravity exerted on an object immersed in a fluid. It also adds some checks and cleanup to LiftDragPlugin.

You can compare the effect of the BuoyancyPlugin on objects with different densities using [gazebo_models PR 140](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/140/added-submarines-of-varying-density) and the `underwater.world` included in this PR. One submarine will float to the top of the world, one will sink, and the other will stay afloat at a constant height (though it may spin due to its off-balance center of gravity). You should be able to get the yellow submarine to propel itself by using the left-hand menu to spin its propeller joint at a constant velocity. This is not due to buoyancy alone; the submarines also use the LiftDragPlugin.

The implementation uses Archimedes' principle, which you can read about on [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buoyancy):

```
object density / fluid density = weight / weight of displaced fluid
```

where "weight" is the force on the object due to gravity, `mass*gravity`. The "weight of the displaced fluid" is the buoyancy force. Thus we are solving for

```
buoyancy = -(mass*gravity*fluid density/object density)
```

The negative sign is included because buoyancy opposes gravity.

Since `density = mass/volume`, the mass term cancels and we get

```
buoyancy = gravity*fluid density*object volume
```

We then exert the buoyancy force on the object by calculating buoyancy for each link and calling `Link::AddLinkForce`.

@scpeters has an alternative way of deriving the buoyancy force by thinking about the pressure exerted on the object due to the fluid, and it gives the same result. Ask him to explain this alternative derivation if you aren't satisfied with the math presented here.
update.title: BuoyancyPlugin for fluid dynamics simulation

content.raw:
thanks! this kind of checks usually helps a lot when a user (or us) made errors with the physics parameters.

I would say, in the case of not being totally sure about an error but most of the chances will mean that, could be enough to just use gzWarn so we have somewhat a hint about the problem.
content.html:
thanks! this kind of checks usually helps a lot when a user (or us) made errors with the physics parameters.

I would say, in the case of not being totally sure about an error but most of the chances will mean that, could be enough to just use gzWarn so we have somewhat a hint about the problem.

content.raw:
111e410 I've added checks that only a positive, non-zero number can be added for volume. I can't think of any great checks on center of volume, however.

Maybe to be extra safe I could check if the center of volume is outside of the link's bounding box, but it's not 100% accurate.
content.html:
111e410 I've added checks that only a positive, non-zero number can be added for volume. I can't think of any great checks on center of volume, however.

Maybe to be extra safe I could check if the center of volume is outside of the link's bounding box, but it's not 100% accurate.

content.raw:
I tried to do the simplest things to make this safe in 111e410.

I added checks for each element/attribute and exit if one of the elements is missing, leaving no trace of the ID in the map. I also check if the ID has already been added to the map and simply skip it if it has.

I could add more documentation about this behavior if needed.
content.html:
I tried to do the simplest things to make this safe in 111e410.

I added checks for each element/attribute and exit if one of the elements is missing, leaving no trace of the ID in the map. I also check if the ID has already been added to the map and simply skip it if it has.

I could add more documentation about this behavior if needed.

content.raw:
yeah, 5000 newton meters is a lot!

It's a bit crude, but I've changed the GZ_ASSERTs to set the value of `cosAlpha` to well within the domain of arccos if it's over. Let me know if you still see the crash.
content.html:
yeah, 5000 newton meters is a lot!

It's a bit crude, but I've changed the GZ_ASSERTs to set the value of cosAlpha to well within the domain of arccos if it's over. Let me know if you still see the crash.

update.description:
This pull request introduces the BuoyancyPlugin, which simulates the force opposing gravity exerted on an object immersed in a fluid. It also adds some checks and cleanup to LiftDragPlugin.

You can compare the effect of the BuoyancyPlugin on objects with different densities using [gazebo_models PR 140](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/140/added-submarines-of-varying-density) and the `underwater.world` included in this PR. One submarine will float to the top of the world, one will sink, and the other will stay afloat at a constant height (though it may spin due to its off-balance center of gravity). You should be able to get the yellow submarine to propel itself by using the left-hand menu to spin its propeller joint at a constant velocity. This is not due to buoyancy alone; the submarines also use the LiftDragPlugin.

The implementation uses Archimedes' principle, which you can read about on [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buoyancy):

```
object density / fluid density = weight / weight of displaced fluid
```

where "weight" is the force on the object due to gravity, `mass*gravity`. The "weight of the displaced fluid" is the buoyancy force. Thus we are solving for

```
buoyancy = -(mass*gravity*fluid density/object density)
```

The negative sign is included because buoyancy opposes gravity.

Since `density = mass/volume`, the mass term cancels and we get

```
buoyancy = gravity*fluid density*object volume
```

We then exert the buoyancy force on the object by calculating buoyancy for each link and calling `Link::AddLinkForce`.

@scpeters has an alternative way of deriving the buoyancy force by thinking about the pressure exerted on the object due to the fluid, and it gives the same result. Ask him to explain this alternative derivation if you aren't satisfied with the math presented here.

content.raw: Default value of id here is -1, I can not understand why. There is a chance that is the linkElem does not have a name, this -1 ends up as the index of the map in the assignations of lines 73 and 79. Is this a valid case and are we considering the consequences of having a map with a -1 entry?
content.html: Default value of id here is -1, I can not understand why. There is a chance that is the linkElem does not have a name, this -1 ends up as the index of the map in the assignations of lines 73 and 79. Is this a valid case and are we considering the consequences of having a map with a -1 entry?

content.raw:
when I gave the yellow submarine's `spinning_joint` a high torque, e.g. 5000, it went forward but became unstable and gazebo eventually crashed with this error:

~~~
***** Internal Program Error - assertion (cosAlpha <= 1) failed in virtual void gazebo::LiftDragPlugin::OnUpdate():
/home/ian/depot/clones/gazebo2/plugins/LiftDragPlugin.cc(191): cosAlpha greater than domain for arccos!
~~~

Maybe I'm doing something I'm not supposed to? but it would nice to prevent the crash
content.html:
when I gave the yellow submarine's spinning_joint a high torque, e.g. 5000, it went forward but became unstable and gazebo eventually crashed with this error:

***** Internal Program Error - assertion (cosAlpha <= 1) failed in virtual void gazebo::LiftDragPlugin::OnUpdate():
/home/ian/depot/clones/gazebo2/plugins/LiftDragPlugin.cc(191): cosAlpha greater than domain for arccos!

Maybe I'm doing something I'm not supposed to? but it would nice to prevent the crash

update.description:
This pull request introduces the BuoyancyPlugin, which simulates the force opposing gravity exerted on an object immersed in a fluid. It also adds some checks and cleanup to LiftDragPlugin.

You can compare the effect of the BuoyancyPlugin on objects with different densities using [gazebo_models PR 140](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/140/added-submarines-of-varying-density) and the `underwater.world` included in this PR. One submarine will float to the top of the world, one will sink, and the other will stay afloat at a constant height (though it may spin due to its off-balance center of gravity). You should be able to get the yellow submarine to propel itself by using the left-hand menu to spin its propeller joint at a constant velocity. This is not due to buoyancy alone; the submarines also use the LiftDragPlugin.

The implementation uses Archimedes' principle, which you can read about on [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buoyancy):

```
object density / fluid density = weight / weight of displaced fluid
```

where "weight" is the force on the object due to gravity, `mass*gravity`. The "weight of the displaced fluid" is the buoyancy force. Thus we are solving for

```
buoyancy = -(mass*gravity*fluid density/object density)
```

The negative sign is included because buoyancy opposes gravity.

Since `density = mass/volume`, the mass term cancels and we get

```
buoyancy = gravity*fluid density*object volume
```

We then exert the buoyancy force on the object by calculating buoyancy for each link and calling `Link::AddLinkForce`.

@scpeters has an alternative way of deriving the buoyancy force by thinking about the pressure exerted on the object due to the fluid, and it gives the same result. Ask him to explain this alternative derivation if you aren't satisfied with the math presented here.
update.title: BuoyancyPlugin for fluid dynamics simulation

1a17d1e
1a17d1e

update.description:
This pull request introduces the BuoyancyPlugin, which simulates the force opposing gravity exerted on an object immersed in a fluid. It also adds some checks and cleanup to LiftDragPlugin.

You can compare the effect of the BuoyancyPlugin on objects with different densities using [gazebo_models PR 140](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/140/added-submarines-of-varying-density) and the `underwater.world` included in this PR. One submarine will float to the top of the world, one will sink, and the other will stay afloat at a constant height (though it may spin due to its off-balance center of gravity). You should be able to get the yellow submarine to propel itself by using the left-hand menu to spin its propeller joint at a constant velocity. This is not due to buoyancy alone; the submarines also use the LiftDragPlugin.

The implementation uses Archimedes' principle, which you can read about on [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buoyancy):

```
object density / fluid density = weight / weight of displaced fluid
```

where "weight" is the force on the object due to gravity, `mass*gravity`. The "weight of the displaced fluid" is the buoyancy force. Thus we are solving for

```
buoyancy = -(mass*gravity*fluid density/object density)
```

The negative sign is included because buoyancy opposes gravity.

Since `density = mass/volume`, the mass term cancels and we get

```
buoyancy = gravity*fluid density*object volume
```

We then exert the buoyancy force on the object by calculating buoyancy for each link and calling `Link::AddLinkForce`.

@scpeters has an alternative way of deriving the buoyancy force by thinking about the pressure exerted on the object due to the fluid, and it gives the same result. Ask him to explain this alternative derivation if you aren't satisfied with the math presented here.
update.title: BuoyancyPlugin for fluid dynamics simulation

update.description:
This pull request introduces the BuoyancyPlugin, which simulates the force opposing gravity exerted on an object immersed in a fluid. It also adds some checks and cleanup to LiftDragPlugin.

You should be able to get the yellow submarine to propel itself by using the left-hand menu to spin its propeller joint at a constant velocity. This is not due to buoyancy alone; the submarines also use the LiftDragPlugin.

The implementation uses Archimedes' principle, which you can read about on [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buoyancy):

